Award.AwardTitle: 2010 FASEB Summer Conference on the Biology of Integrated Nuclear and Extranuclear Steroid Signaling. Conference Program August 8 - 12, 2010, Aspen Snowmass, CO
Award.AbstractNarration: The synthesis, release and actions of steroid hormones such as estrogens, progesterone, testosterone, and cortisol are vital for normal daily living. For example, the absence of cortisol production is incompatible with life, and insufficient estrogen production in women leads to hot flashes, osteoporosis and infertility. In addition, steroids promote the growth of some cancers. The purpose of this conference is to bring together world-renowned scientists studying the effects of steroid hormones in the brain and other organ systems (heart, pancreas, gonads, colon, etc.). The overarching goal is to develop broad new concepts about the way in which steroids have immediate impact on individual cells in various organ systems as well as long term effects on growth and development of organ systems. This meeting will not only foster new collaborations among the experts in the field but will also provide a venue for junior scientists of diverse background to interact and collaborate with these expert leaders. Moreover, the FASEB conference will foster the development of novel systems level biological approaches toward understanding the communication networks (via blood, nerves, etc.) involved in steroid actions throughout the body. The cross-talk between this distinguished group of scientists, which include marine biologists that work on simple marine organisms and physicians that treat patients, will allow the development of common research approaches to better understand endocrine systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summer Conferences on the Biology of Integrated Nuclear and Extranuclear Steroid Signaling

 

The 2010 and 2012 FASEB Summer Research Conferences entitled “The Physiology of Integrated Nuclear and Extra-nuclear Steroid Signaling" and  “Integration of Genomic and Non-genomic Steroid Receptor Actions,” respectively, convened from late July through early August (over five days) in 2010 and 2012 at Snowmass Village, CO.  The programs were chaired jointly by Stephen R. Hammes (University of Rochester), Martin J. Kelly (Oregon Health & Science University) and Joyce M. Slingerland (University of Miami). The purpose of these conferences was to build new bridges and create collaborations in the field of steroid hormone (e.g., estrogen, progesterone, and testosterone) signaling.  To achieve this goal, the meetings brought together established leaders in the field, up and coming junior scientists, and a cadre of trainees, all of whom spent the entire meeting working, eating, and socializing together.  Overall, more than 60 scientists participated in these conferences – a size suitable to create diversity and breadth, but still small enough to promote substantial cross-talk and personal interactions among faculty and fellows.

 

The meetings consisted of seven scientific sessions that included twenty-eight established investigators as well as a young investigator symposium that included eight invited trainees. These talks were given by a wide array of international speakers from North and South America, as well as Europe and Asia.  Posters from scientists all over the world were presented as well.

 

The subject material was diverse and included nearly every aspect steroid hormone signaling.  Examples include steroid hormone effects on both male and female reproduction, heart function, brain function, and cell biology.  After every presentation, discussion was lively and formative, and, by the end of the meetings, all participants felt that they had both learned a great deal of new and important information.  In addition, the meetings served as a vehicle to create new collaborations between trainees and both junior and senior scientists.  In fact, after the meeting, organizers received several emails from grateful trainees and young faculty (see Table 1), prompting them to begin planning the next meeting in 2015.  Finally, over 15 participants, mostly trainees and young faculty, published papers based on their talks presented at the meeting in the prominent hormone journal called STEROIDs (Steroids 76:821, 2011 and Steroids 78:528, 2013), thus leaving an everlasting record of this occasion in the scientific literature.   


Table 1: Testimonials from Trainees Attending FASEB Summer Conferences

 

I can honestly say that I got a lot more out of the FASEB conference than any other meeting that I have been to. I really liked the interdisciplinary, yet focused nature of this meeting as it forced me to learn about steroid action in other parts of the body I was less familiar with highlighting similarities and differences between the different anatomical structures. At the FASEB meeting, the small relatively informal setting allowed for a more even, less intimidating setting for a graduate student like myself to exchange ideas with senior scientists. Having a good mixture of fellows, graduate students, and senior scientists was key in creating a wonderful scientific atmosphere. I truly had a wonderful experience. (Brian Kenealy, Graduate Student, Endocrinology and Reproductive Training program, University of Wisconsin- Madison)
